Taxpayers have a right to know how their dollars are being spent by the federal government. We are all aware of the amount of waste when it comes to government spending, but you'd be shocked at how hard it is to obtain detailed information to pinpoint where the waste occurs.   This week we passed a bill that requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to provide more online information about the cost and performance of federal programs that exceed $1 million in budget authority, such as program activities, funding amounts, performance information on awards or other financial assistance, and program evaluations.  This is the sort of initiatives we need to get a handle on wasteful spending, tighten our books and get the budget in order. We're excited to see this bill - and others like it - through the legislative process and into law so that we can get our country's financial house in order. https://gallery.mailchimp.com/301a28247b80ab82279e92afb/files/Legislative_Digest_H.R.______Taxpayers_Right_To_Know_Act.01.pdf

The U.S. is one of the permanent members of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC), along with the U.K., France, Russia and China. Being part of this group gives us the important power to veto any resolution that is not in the interest of our nation or our allies. The Obama Administration recently failed to exercise its veto power on UNSC Resolution 2334, which classifies the Jewish Quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem and the Western Wall, Judaism’s holiest site, as “occupied territory,” effectively allowing for Palestinian occupation of these areas.   Since 1972, the U.S. has vetoed 42 anti-Israel resolutions like this one. I strongly oppose the Obama Administration’s abstention – the resolution in question severely undermines the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. If any solution is to be realized, it must come from bilateral negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, not through the United Nations.   Only weeks before this vote, Russia and China exercised their own respective veto power to strike down a UNSC resolution that would have initiated a seven day ceasefire in Aleppo, Syria in order to allow for humanitarian aid and to resume settlement talks. While Russia and China have made clear that they intend to continue vetoing resolutions that are in conflict with their Syrian allies, the U.S. must make clear that we will stand by our Israeli allies.   The House passed H.Res. 11 this week, which opposes UNSC Resolution 2334 and calls for its repeal. I was proud to vote in favor of this legislation and would urge the incoming Administration to reject resolutions like this one, which obstruct the peace process and are counterproductive to a safe, strong Israel.

The House is set to pass a regulatory reform package today that includes our PROVE IT Act - a bill we introduced last Congress that will bring fairness, transparency and accountability to the federal regulatory system.  Since 2008, nearly 3,300 NEW federal regulations are imposed on job creators and workers every year. It's estimated that these regulations impose a $1.9 trillion burden on consumers and entrepreneurs while raising prices, reducing choice, and making it harder to start businesses (much less, run one!).   At the state level, the real-world impact of regulations vary depending on the unique mix of industries in a given state. Since regulations are designed to target particular sectors of the economy, states like Louisiana that have a concentrated mix of targeted industries will disproportionately feel the impact of those regs.   One study (published by George Mason's Mercatus Center) ranks states by the extent to which regulations impact their economies. Louisiana was on top of that list and found that the impact of federal regulation on Louisiana industries was 74 percent higher than the impact on the nation overall. (Main drivers of this ranking are Louisiana's chemical products manufacturing and oil and gas industries.)   We've made reducing current burdens on our businesses and consumers and preventing future, unnecessary and exorbitant regulatory costs a top priority of our service in Congress, and today marks an important step in a better direction for America.

Today marked 26 years since the start of Operation Desert Storm, the second phase of the Persian Gulf War. After Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait in August of 1990, the United Nations struck back with an embargo and sanctions on Iraq and the U.S. Congress authorized the use of military force to drive Iraqi forces out of Kuwait. The U.S.-led coalition of countries began its campaign on January 17, 1991 at approximately 3:00am local time. By February 28 of that year Iraqi troops had retreated and the U.S. declared suspension of the offensive.   This successful campaign reminds us all that the U.S. and its allies remain a global force for good - able to defeat any entity that works against peace in the world.    Before the operation began, President George H.W. Bush commented that he was “convinced not only that we will prevail, but that out of the horror of combat will come the recognition that no nation can stand against a world united. No nation will be permitted to brutally assault its neighbor.” These words continue to resonate with me even 26 years later.   https://history.state.gov/milestones/1989-1992/gulf-war

The Comite River Diversion Canal should be built to provide flood protection for area residents and improve our regional resiliency. While it will not solve all flood risk, Comite would benefit the most people in the shortest time.    The project could be completed in approximately two years – and the state has the federal funds available now to build it. Through funds appropriated by Congress, Louisiana has more than $250 million in available flood and disaster prevention funds.  With these Hazard Mitigation Grant Program funds, the state just has to prioritize the goals of the Comite project and move forward.     Completing the project would also lower the region’s base flood elevation and eliminates the need for many home and business owners from having to raise their homes, which carries a price tag few can afford.    Comite should have been completed decades ago, but now we actually have the opportunity to do it. Let’s commit and reduce long term risk for our people and their property from potential future flood events.

After many meetings and calls with the agency, we're happy to announce that FEMA will extend the proof of loss deadline for our flooded friends and families in South Louisiana, allowing a total of 270 days to provide their completed proof of loss to their insurer.   See the official word from FEMA below, and don't hesitate to contact our office if we can be of assistance.   ###   The Standard Flood Insurance Policy (SFIP) requires a policyholder to send the insurer a complete, signed, and sworn proof of loss within 60 days after the date of loss.  Due to the significant, widespread flooding that occurred in portions of Louisiana between August 9, 2016 and August 31, 2016, FEMA issued two Write Your Own (WYO) Bulletins extending the proof of loss deadline:   • WYO Bulletin W-16067 (September 9, 2016) – 60 Day Extension • WYO Bulletin W-16089 (December 2, 2016) – 60 Day Extension   To allow policyholders time to finalize their claims, an additional limited waiver of the 60-day proof of loss requirement has been issued, extending the period an additional 90 days.  With this extension, a National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) policyholder will have a total of 270 days after the date of loss to provide the completed, signed, and sworn-to proof of loss to the insurer.  This waiver is issued pursuant to 44 CFR § 61.13(d) and the SFIP.  This waiver does not alter any other terms or conditions of the SFIP.   In order to expedite the recovery process, policyholders are urged to submit a proof of loss as soon as possible.  Policyholders should contact their insurer for assistance with filing a proof of loss.

If, on average, four people ride on a boat, that means each day 6,484 boats would have to leave docks along the Gulf Coast, every day.  For those numbers to make sense, you would literally have to have hundreds or thousands of boats leaving all of those Gulf Coast docks, every day.' Proudly supported today's House passage of bill designed to bring more accountability to how agencies spend your money, HR 1004 - the Regulatory Integrity Act.   Under H.R. 1004, agencies would be barred from communicating through social media and other means to promote or solicit public support for agency actions.  The bill would also set requirements for communications that are allowed and would direct agencies to disclose additional information about regulatory activities.  In a December 2015 letter, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) said that Environmental Protection Agency communications related to the “Waters of the U.S.” rule violated prohibitions on spending money on publicity, propaganda and grassroots lobbying.   In another instance, the Homeland Security Department didn’t provide advance notice or an opportunity for public comment when it adopted the DAPA policy granting deferred action to undocumented immigrants with children who are U.S. citizens, according to a report on the bill from the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.  Agencies should be focused on their core mission and use what resources are available for communications to raise the public's awareness/solicit public comment - not to push an agenda. This is true regardless of which party is in the White House. We've spent an enormous amount of time hearing from and talking with constituents about healthcare over the last 24+ months, interacting with people who have been hurt by the Affordable Care Act and with people who were helped by it. Each of us have personal opinions on the law that are drawn mostly from experience (my family has an ACA plan, and we're paying more and getting less - others have a different story).   The objectives of comprehensive healthcare reform 8 years ago were pretty straightforward: improve access and quality, and lower costs. I support all of those objectives - but those objectives have not been met.   In the aggregate, we're worse off now than we were before:  • Premiums have increased by an average of 25% just this year. • Nearly 1/3 of all U.S. counties have only 1 insurer offering plans on their state’s exchange. • 34% fewer doctors and other health care providers accept Obamacare insurance compared to private insurance.   These are just a few examples...   Some core tenets of the American Health Care Act are to deliver relief from the individual and employer tax burdens required through the ACA, eliminate mandates that force people who don't want insurance into buying it, preserve important patient protections (pre-existing conditions/dependents staying on until 26) while creating mechanisms that give providers, payers and patients the opportunity to innovate the way care is delivered.   Encourage you to continue weighing in with our office so that we can keep incorporating your feedback into the process as this thing moves forward.  http://housegop.leadpages.co/healthcare/

Registration Deadline for Tornado Survivors is April 12, 2017 Tornado survivors in Livingston and Orleans parishes have two weeks to register for assistance with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).  The deadline to register is Wednesday, April 12, 2017. Survivors may register with FEMA by going online with any computer, smartphone or tablet to DisasterAssistance.gov, calling the FEMA helpline at 800-621-3362, or downloading the FEMA mobile app. Survivors who are deaf, hard of hearing or have a speech disability and who use a TTY may call 800-462-7585 to register.   FEMA assistance for homeowners and renters may include grants for rent, temporary housing and home repair to their primary residence, as well as other serious disaster-related needs, such as medical and dental expenses or funeral and burial costs. Also, the deadline to submit a disaster loan application with the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) is Wednesday, April 12, 2017. SBA disaster loans are available to help businesses of all sizes, private nonprofit organizations, homeowners and renters with their recovery efforts. Submitting a loan application does not imply acceptance of a loan, but it is a necessary step in recovery and to be considered for other forms of disaster assistance. For more information, applicants may contact SBA’s Disaster Assistance Customer Service Center by calling 800-659-2955, emailing disastercustomerservice@sba.gov, or visiting SBA’s website at SBA.gov/disaster. Deaf and hard-of-hearing individuals may call 800-877-8339. SBA representatives are also available at any disaster loan outreach center, or business recovery center.

Today, HUD approved the state’s Action Plan Amendment, which means a total of $1,656,972,000 has been made available to Louisiana for flood recovery, pending simple administrative action from the state.   Sec. Carson’s office says that the state can start drawing down money from this line of credit upon both parties signing a letter sent to the governor this afternoon.   This means that the state now has the go ahead to mobilize its plan (is the plan ready?) and obligate funds. The process is simple: the state submits work orders/draws that are paid within 48 hours.  (What stops the state from having a pile of these ready to go?)  Here’s why we’re frustrated:  HUD informed us today that the state asked them to not release the $438 million appropriated in September until the Action Plan for the second tranche of money was also approved. That's like refusing to throw a drowning person a life raft because you're waiting on the rescue boat to come. Makes no sense.   You'd think the extra time would allow the state to ensure its spend plan was locked and loaded in preparation of the second approval.   Nope. In the state’s own words: “the Restore Louisiana Homeowner Assistance Program will begin in early April. It will consist of two main parts – an initial survey and the application [emphasis added]. The survey determines when a homeowner may apply for assistance.” So, the program starts mid-April with… paperwork. Only to be followed up with… a determination of when you may apply for assistance. But what about actually getting the assistance and when?  Further, the state says that “when the survey becomes available in April, more information will be available.” …So even at some undetermined time in April, even after the line of credit has been established, still NO money will go to homeowners. Not a single dollar will be going into a home until possibly 9 months after the flood – that’s outrageous.   The point is that this timeline could have been shortened had things been done more efficiently by the state.   It's April. The flood happened in August. This isn't a victory, it's a shame.If money was approved in September, how can anyone be content with April/May relief?

Happy to announce that NOAA is providing a $1.32 million grant to Louisiana as ongoing funding through the National Coastal Zone Management Program to help administer the state's federally approved coastal management program.  The National Coastal Zone Management Program is a critically important voluntary federal-state partnership that protects, restores, and responsibly develops our nation's coastal communities and resources by balancing economic development, coastal uses, and natural resource protection.   NOAA's investment of more than $5.3M over FY16 and FY17 is leveraging over $4.3M in state funds.These funds will support jobs and provide continued assistance to the Louisiana coastal management program to address many important coastal issues in the state including coastal hazards, habitat protection and restoration, and water quality.  For example, one project will begin a process to develop new and revised standard operating procedures for Local Coastal Parish programs related to floodplain mitigation and participation in the National Flood Insurance Program and the Community Rating System. These new procedures will help increase community resilience and guard against hazards by improving construction and development in high hazard areas of coastal Louisiana.   The funding also supports ongoing coastal wetland permitting, with the goal of achieving no net loss of Louisiana wetlands from development activities. Coastal wetland permitting also includes coordination with the Local Coastal Parish program, through which the state provides technical assistance support to local parish governments on permitting issues of local concern related to coastal management.   http://www.dnr.louisiana.gov/assets/OCM/CoastalZoneBoundary/CZB2012/maps/Overview_of_Revised_CZB.pdf

This week we met with a group of patient advocates from various disease groups we hosted for another healthcare round-table discussion. We've been holding these meetings with stakeholders from all corners of the healthcare continuum - patients, doctors and other providers, payers, the Medicaid plans, etc.   The conversation was constructive and helpful, and the respectful back-and-forth served all of us well as we discussed their challenges and the unique obstacles people with chronic conditions face. We talked through some legitimate concerns people have with the AHCA and were able to clear up some of the misconceptions about the bill.    Story after story reaffirmed the extraordinary financial, regulatory and access  challenges present throughout our current system, but I'm encouraged by the thoughtful dialogue and will use the ideas discussed to continue to advocate for our constituents as the current and subsequent reform bills work through the Senate and the legislative process.

One of the things we've been talking about and working on to lower costs in healthcare is increasing patients' ability to act like consumers  - meaning people should have access to the information necessary to make purchase decisions based on their own considerations of things like value, need and affordability. When you go to the grocery store for example, you have all the info needed to decide whether to buy name brand or store brand and you're the one who decides based on circumstance, finances, preference, etc... That's not the case in healthcare today. How many times have we all gone to the pharmacy to get a prescription filled, approached the counter and literally had no clue whether we were about to pay $10 or $100 or more? And that's just one example.   Lee Zurik rolled out a new investigative series that takes a deeper look into how the lack of transparency in healthcare can distort prices and hurt people. I highly recommend you watch it.   We're continuing to work on policy changes to advance consumer practice in healthcare too, so stay tuned for more details to come.   http://www.fox8live.com/story/35334208/zurik-absolutely-ridiculous-medical-bills-show-critical-need-for-transparency

PRESS RELEASE:  Congressman Garret Graves (R-LA) recently introduced the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) Reform Act of 2017 to require the program to do more to connect the unemployed with existing job placement and job training opportunities so that more people who are able to work can. Graves introduced the bill to fight poverty, support families and promote self-sufficiency while helping stem the tide of government dependence.  Graves’ legislation builds upon the successful track record of mandatory federal work requirements first established in President Bill Clinton’s 1996 “welfare reform,” taking a similar approach to strengthen the work requirements for “able-bodied adults without dependents” who are food stamp recipients through SNAP.  “There are talented people across our country who aren’t pursuing the full potential of their capabilities largely because government incentives make it more profitable in some cases to stay home and collect welfare than to pursue personal growth and responsibility through work,” said Graves. “Government needs to provide a safety net for the vulnerable, but it’s become a lifestyle for some to actively choose government assistance over work – that’s a disservice to those people, the economy and the taxpayer. We have to restructure incentives to achieve the outcomes we want and to get capable people off the sidelines and involved in building America’s future. This bill is a small step toward that goal.”   Click the link to read more. https://garretgraves.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/graves-introduces-common-sense-snap-reform-bill

WHO:            The extended deadline applies to all policyholders who filed a flood claim following the August 2016 severe storms in southern Louisiana. Currently, Congress takes a reactionary approach to natural disasters: It draws up a disaster relief bill, the president signs it and we all kind of move on to the next fight. We've been outspoken about shifting the federal paradigm on disaster management and community resilience. US Taxpayers have spent hundreds of billions of dollars on disaster response, but a fraction of that could have been spent to largely prevent disaster damages. Multiple government and independent reports show that every one dollar invested in prevention and resiliency saves as much as four dollars in disaster response costs. But our government is stuck on stupid: instead of making these investments on the front-end, it’s dead-set on this broken process of coming in after a disaster and spending exponentially more dollars.   We have to break this cycle and redesign policies around resiliency to stop hemorrhaging billions of dollars after the fact - that approach is wasteful and leaves our communities, economies and ecosystems just as susceptible as they were before the event. Was privileged to recognize LIGO founders on the House Floor yesterday.   ### Nobel Prize Awarded to LIGO (via the Advocate)   In a week darkened by terrible news, the announcement of a Nobel Prize award for an LSU professor is an especially welcome reminder of the wonder of human possibility.  Rainer Weiss, an LSU adjunct professor and MIT professor emeritus, will share this year's Nobel Prize in physics with California Institute of Technology professors emeriti Barry Barish and Kip Thorne. The professors were recognized for advancing the world's first detection of gravitational waves, a development made possible by a large research facility in Livingston Parish.  The parish is home to a Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory, or LIGO; companion facilities operate in Hanford, Washington, and Pisa, Italy.  Albert Einstein theorized the world was shaped by gravitational waves, and thanks to LIGO researchers, we now have physical proof.  With admirable humility, Weiss said the Nobel really recognizes the work of thousands. Among that number are the many local researchers and officials who helped make LIGO's work possible. We congratulate them all on a stellar honor.

There was nothing unexpected about yesterday’s projection at all – in fact, we predicted this would happen going back to early 2016 (https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-2016-02-12/pdf/CREC-2016-02-12-pt1-PgH811-2.pdf and https://garretgraves.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/garret-graves-final-well-control-rule-why-america-hates-our-federal).   The lede should be “Shortfall in coastal funding the predictable consequence of uniformed policymaking,” and the rest of the story should be an explanation of how this is an example of the impact of regulations when they are not fully thought through and that federal policy decisions have lasting effects. The story seems to suggest that the revenue shortfall is because of proposals to cut the GOMESA program, but that’s a misunderstanding of reality; GOMESA is intact (watch this video for more on that: https://www.facebook.com/CongressmanGarretGraves/videos/777132952466789/).   Here’s what’s really going on. GOMESA funding – by design – is directly correlated to production levels. When there’s less production, there’s less revenue for coastal projects. There’s less production today in part because of offshore energy policies that go back to President Obama: the moratorium/permatorium in 2011 and the well control/BOP regulation finalized in 2016, which has been a functional moratorium on production in the Gulf.    What’s ironic is that these policies where pushed under a pretext of “protecting the environment,” but it’s clear now (as we predicted then: https://www.facebook.com/CongressmanGarretGraves/videos/527256207454466/ )that these policies are actually harming the environment by preventing restoration and will result in more federal expenditures by delaying important flood control projects.

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 1:   LOWERS INDIVIDUAL TAX RATES FOR LOW- AND MIDDLE-INCOME AMERICANS.   The bill lowers individual tax rates for low- and middle-income Americans to Zero, 12%, 25%, and 35% so people can keep more of the money they earn throughout their lives, and continues to maintain 39.6% for high-income Americans.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 2:   SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASES THE STANDARD DEDUCTION AND ESTABLISHES A NEW FAMILY CREDIT  The bill significantly increases the standard deduction to protect roughly double the amount of what you earn each year from taxes – from $6,350 to $12,000 for individuals and $12,700 to $24,000 for married couples. Establishes a new Family Credit, which includes expanding the Child Tax Credit from $1,000 to $1,600 to help parents with the cost of raising children, and providing a credit of $300 for each parent and non-child dependent to help all families with their everyday expenses.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 3:  PRESERVES THE HOME MORTGAGE INTEREST DEDUCTION  The bill reserves the home mortgage interest deduction for existing mortgages and maintains the home mortgage interest deduction for newly purchased homes up to $500,000 – providing tax relief to current and aspiring homeowners. Continues to allow people to write off the cost of state and local property taxes up to $10,000.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 4:  PREVENTS AMERICAN JOBS, HEADQUARTERS, AND RESEARCH FROM MOVING OVERSEAS   The bill prevents American jobs, headquarters, and research from moving overseas by eliminating incentives that now reward companies for shifting jobs, profits, and manufacturing plants abroad.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 5:  ELIMINATES SPECIAL-INTEREST DEDUCTIONS THAT INCREASE RATES AND COMPLICATE AMERICANS’ TAXES  The bill eliminates special-interest deductions that increase rates and complicate Americans’ taxes – so an individual or family can file their taxes on a form as simple as a postcard.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 6:  REPEALS THE DEATH TAX AND ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX (AMT)   The bill provides immediate relief from the Death Tax by doubling the exemption and repealing the Death Tax after six years. Family-owned farms and businesses will no longer have to worry about double or triple taxation from Washington when they pass down their life’s work to the next generation. Repeals the Alternative Minimum Tax so millions of individuals and families will no longer have to worry about calculating their taxes twice each year and pay the higher amount.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 7:  REDUCES THE TAX RATE ON THE HARD-EARNED BUSINESS INCOME OF MAIN STREET JOB CREATORS  The bill reduces the tax rate on the hard-earned business income of Main Street job creators to no more than 25% – the lowest tax rate on small business income since World War II. It also allows businesses to immediately write off the full cost of new equipment to improve operations and enhance the skills of their workers – unleashing the growth of jobs, productivity, and paychecks.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

What the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act does, PART 8:  LOWERS THE CORPORATE TAX RATE TO 20%  The bill lowers the corporate tax rate to 20% – down from 35%, which today is the highest in the industrialized world – the largest reduction in the U.S. corporate tax rate in our nation’s history.  https://garretgraves.house.gov/issues/tax-reform

Positive news and a nod to the superiority of state-based science. Per NOAA:   ### Today, NOAA Fisheries will announce the certification of the Louisiana Recreational Creel (LA Creel) survey design. The Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) uses LA Creel as an alternative general survey to estimate recreational fishing catch and effort. It was designed to provide catch estimates for state drainage basins, particularly for offshore fisheries, that are more precise than the Marine Recreational Information Program (MRIP) general survey estimates, and also to provide preliminary estimates weekly during the fishing season.   Since 2014, Louisiana and NOAA Fisheries, along with outside consultants, have been working collaboratively to develop and refine the LA Creel sampling and estimation methods. LDFW developed the survey design, and MRIP provided technical support for subsequent improvement. MRIP also coordinated the independent peer review of the design.   Now that the LA Creel survey design has been certified, it is eligible for federal funding to support ongoing improvements and implementation. Use of LA Creel catch statistics in stock assessments and management actions requires their conversion into a "common currency" that makes them comparable to historical MRIP estimates. Implementation of such a conversion requires development of peer-reviewed scientifically valid methods.   LA Creel is one of several Gulf of Mexico surveys that has been developed by the States with technical support from MRIP. Survey designs to supplement MRIP catch and effort estimates for red snapper are currently under review for certification in Alabama and Mississippi. Additionally, Florida has developed a supplemental reef fish survey design that will be peer reviewed in February 2018.   The process of supporting the development and certification of new survey designs demonstrates MRIP's commitment to working with our State and regional partners to meet their unique data needs and advance new methods and technologies. This is critical to improving recreational fishing data collection efforts and ensuring fishing opportunities for future generations.  http://www.wlf.louisiana.gov/lacreel
